newsitem.title: DUBAI: Crescent Petroleum in talks with foreign firms.
newsitem.headline: Crescent Petroleum in talks with foreign firms.

text.p: Crescent Petroleum Company International Ltd on Monday confirmed it was in talks with several foreign firms on future strategic alliances and a possible equity sale in the Sharjah-based private oil firm.
"The company has been in discussions with several international companies seeking strategic alliances," a spokeman for Crescent said.
Crescent had been approached with offers of entering partnerships in "areas of mutal interest" and the possible sale of a minority equity stake in the firm.
"In addition to companies from the Far East, including Taiwan and South Korea, discussions have been held with European as well as Canadian oil firms," the spokesman said.
Taiwan's state-owned Chinese Petroleum Corp was in talks with Crescent to buy a 40 percent stake in a Crescent affiliate, a statement released by the Taipei economics ministry said on Monday.
Crescent's spokesman said that they had not been approached with the offer and that a deal was not imminent.
"No agreement has been concluded with any entity...No offers have been given to or received from Taiwan's CPC," he said.
Taiwan's Central News Agency also reported on Monday that CPC had offered $80 million to secure the 40 percent stake.
The Sharjah-based firm has oil and gas producing assets in the gulf and interests in a Pakistan refinery project and a planned gas project to transport and sell gas from Qatar to Pakistan.
Crescent's Buttes Gas and Oil and exploration firm Enterprise Oil Plc signed a $70 million venture in July 1996 to fund exploration and production activities offshore Sharjah.
